thread.title: ‘Everyday Dale’ has his 14,641-day surfin’ safari wiped out … by kidney stones
thread.title_full: ‘Everyday Dale’ has his 14,641-day surfin’ safari wiped out … by kidney stones | The Seattle Times

author: Dwight Perry / Sideline Chatter
title: ‘Everyday Dale’ has his 14,641-day surfin’ safari wiped out … by kidney stones
text:
Eat your heart out, Cal Ripken Jr.
“Everyday Dale” Webster — who had surfed three or more waves every day since Sept. 3, 1975, in Sonoma County, Calif. — had his 14,641-day streak snapped Oct. 5 when he underwent kidney-stone surgery. Sounds like the end of the streak — which even the death of his wife and the birth of his daughter couldn’t derail — was something of a relief.
“I don’t want to have to drive to the beach through a flood; I don’t want take my board out of my car during a gale or battle the ocean during a storm,” Webster, 66, told Surfer magazine. “I don’t have to do that stuff any more; I’ve done it.”
Sports quiz Q: What did retired soccer great Juli Veee and the Texas Rangers’ infield have in common this week?
Most Read Stories Seahawks’ Derrick Coleman arrested for investigation of hit, run Mayor wants developer off project, cites violation of city values Police: Woman linked to 1973 disappearance is actually alive Outraged Seattle Public Schools parents, pace yourselves Seattle Seahawks release WR B.J. Daniels, RB Rod Smith Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. A: Three straight E’s.
Some water hazard Don’t want to say the rain was coming down in buckets in Seattle last Saturday, but we swear we saw the golfing priest from “Caddyshack” playing through our front yard.
Sung in the key of B-flat Mike Bianchi of the Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, serenading his state’s three NFL teams — the 2-3 Buccaneers, 1-3 Dolphins and 1-4 Jaguars — to the tune of “Three Blind Mice”:
“Three bad teams; three bad teams; see how they lose; see how they lose;
They fire their coaches; they miss their kicks;
Jameis Winston just threw four picks.
They’re a football version of the New York Knicks;
Three bad teams …”
Clocking out The NFL suspended side judge Rob Vernatchi for one week with pay after he failed to detect the clock operator letting 18 seconds elapse off the clock in the final three minutes of Monday night’s Steelers-Chargers game.
On the bright side, he just clinched this year’s Rosemary Woods Award.
Quote marks • Fantasy-sports inventor (1980) Dan Okrent, to The New York Times, on the FBI probe into cash-cow fantasy websites FanDuel and DraftKings: “I feel like J. Robert Oppenheimer, having invented the atomic bomb. I meant it for peaceful purposes.”
• Scott Ostler of the San Francisco Chronicle, with a title suggestion for a Sepp Blatter biopic: “The Line on Ethics: Bend It Like Blatter.”
• Headline at SportsPickle.com: “Cubs’ 105-year rebuilding plan beginning to bear fruit.”
• Just-retired South Carolina football coach Steve Spurrier, not impressed that he was still coaching at age 70: “The pope is 77 years old, and he’s in charge of a billion people. All I have to do is put 11 on the field.”
Paging Dean Wormer FIFA announced that Sepp Blatter would be “provisionally suspended” for 90 days.
Any more mishaps, the boot poobahs warned, and he’ll be on … on … double-secret probation!
Dwight Perry: 206-464-8250 or dperry@seattletimes.com
